trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Mobile Engagement
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Mobile Engagement

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Engagement with analytics and push notifications for Android apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Engagement with analytics and push notifications for Android apps.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Mobile Engagement for Android apps
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Mobile Engagement for Android apps

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Windows Universal
trans-unit.target: Windows Universal

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone Silverlight
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone Silverlight

trans-unit.source: iOS - Obj C
trans-unit.target: iOS - Obj C

trans-unit.source: iOS - Swift
trans-unit.target: iOS - Swift

trans-unit.source: Android
trans-unit.target: Android

trans-unit.source: Cordova
trans-unit.target: Cordova

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Engagement to understand your app usage and how to send push notifications to segmented users of an Android application.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use Azure Mobile Engagement to understand your app usage and how to send push notifications to segmented users of an Android application.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrates the simple broadcast scenario using Mobile Engagement.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrates the simple broadcast scenario using Mobile Engagement.

trans-unit.source: In it, you create a blank Android app that collects basic data and receives push notifications using Google Cloud Messaging (GCM).
trans-unit.target: In it, you create a blank Android app that collects basic data and receives push notifications using Google Cloud Messaging (GCM).

trans-unit.source: When you have completed this tutorial, you will be able to broadcast push notifications to all the devices or target-specific users based on their devices' properties.
trans-unit.target: When you have completed this tutorial, you will be able to broadcast push notifications to all the devices or target-specific users based on their devices' properties.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to follow along with the next tutorial to see how to use Mobile Engagement to address specific users and groups of devices.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to follow along with the next tutorial to see how to use Mobile Engagement to address specific users and groups of devices.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires the following:

trans-unit.source: The Android SDK (it is assumed you will be using Android Studio), which you can download [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=389797)
trans-unit.target: The Android SDK (it is assumed you will be using Android Studio), which you can download [here](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=389797)

trans-unit.source: The [Mobile Engagement Android SDK]
trans-unit.target: The [Mobile Engagement Android SDK]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Completing this tutorial is a prerequisite for all other Mobile Engagement tutorials for Android apps, and to complete it, you must have an active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Completing this tutorial is a prerequisite for all other Mobile Engagement tutorials for Android apps, and to complete it, you must have an active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see Azure Free Trial.
trans-unit.target: For details, see Azure Free Trial.

trans-unit.source: Set up Mobile Engagement for your app
trans-unit.target: Set up Mobile Engagement for your app

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), and then click **+NEW** at the bottom of the screen.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), and then click **+NEW** at the bottom of the screen.

trans-unit.source: Click **App Services**, click **Mobile Engagement**, and then click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **App Services**, click **Mobile Engagement**, and then click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: In the pop-up that appears, enter the following information:
trans-unit.target: In the pop-up that appears, enter the following information:

trans-unit.source: **Application Name**: You can type the name of your application.
trans-unit.target: **Application Name**: You can type the name of your application.

trans-unit.source: Feel free to use any character.
trans-unit.target: Feel free to use any character.

trans-unit.source: **Platform**: Select the target platform for that app (if your app targets multiple platforms, repeat this tutorial for each platform).
trans-unit.target: **Platform**: Select the target platform for that app (if your app targets multiple platforms, repeat this tutorial for each platform).

trans-unit.source: **Application Resource Name**: This is the name by which this application will be accessible via APIs and URLs.
trans-unit.target: **Application Resource Name**: This is the name by which this application will be accessible via APIs and URLs.

trans-unit.source: We advise that you use only conventional URL characters: The auto-generated name should provide you a strong basis.
trans-unit.target: We advise that you use only conventional URL characters: The auto-generated name should provide you a strong basis.

trans-unit.source: We also advise appending the platform name to avoid any name clash because this name must be unique.
trans-unit.target: We also advise appending the platform name to avoid any name clash because this name must be unique.

trans-unit.source: **Location**: Select the datacenter where this app (and more importantly its Collection - see below) will be hosted.
trans-unit.target: **Location**: Select the datacenter where this app (and more importantly its Collection - see below) will be hosted.

trans-unit.source: **Collection**: If you have already created an application, select a previously created Collection; otherwise select **New Collection**.
trans-unit.target: **Collection**: If you have already created an application, select a previously created Collection; otherwise select **New Collection**.

trans-unit.source: **Collection Name**: This represents your group of applications.
trans-unit.target: **Collection Name**: This represents your group of applications.

trans-unit.source: It will also ensure all your apps are in a group that allows aggregated calculations.
trans-unit.target: It will also ensure all your apps are in a group that allows aggregated calculations.

trans-unit.source: We strongly advise that you use your company name or department.
trans-unit.target: We strongly advise that you use your company name or department.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, click the check mark button to finish the creation of your app.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, click the check mark button to finish the creation of your app.

trans-unit.source: Now click or select the app you just created in the **Application** tab.
trans-unit.target: Now click or select the app you just created in the **Application** tab.

trans-unit.source: Then click **Connection Info** in order to display the **Connection** settings to put into your SDK integration.
trans-unit.target: Then click **Connection Info** in order to display the **Connection** settings to put into your SDK integration.

trans-unit.source: Finally, write down the **Connection String**, which is what you will need to identify this app from your application code.
trans-unit.target: Finally, write down the **Connection String**, which is what you will need to identify this app from your application code.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] You can use the **Copy** icon on the right of the **Connection String** to copy it to the Clipboard as a convenience.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] You can use the **Copy** icon on the right of the **Connection String** to copy it to the Clipboard as a convenience.

trans-unit.source: Connect your app to the Mobile Engagement backend
trans-unit.target: Connect your app to the Mobile Engagement backend

trans-unit.source: This tutorial presents a "basic integration", which is the minimal set required to collect data and send a push notification.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial presents a "basic integration", which is the minimal set required to collect data and send a push notification.

trans-unit.source: The complete integration documentation can be found in the [Mobile Engagement Android SDK documentation].
trans-unit.target: The complete integration documentation can be found in the [Mobile Engagement Android SDK documentation].

trans-unit.source: We will create a basic app with Android Studio to demonstrate the integration.
trans-unit.target: We will create a basic app with Android Studio to demonstrate the integration.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Android project
trans-unit.target: Create a new Android project

trans-unit.source: You can skip this step if you already have an app and are familiar with Android development.
trans-unit.target: You can skip this step if you already have an app and are familiar with Android development.

trans-unit.source: Start **Android Studio**, and in the pop-up, select **Start a new Android Studio project**.
trans-unit.target: Start **Android Studio**, and in the pop-up, select **Start a new Android Studio project**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the app name and company domain.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the app name and company domain.

trans-unit.source: Write them down because you will need them later, and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Write them down because you will need them later, and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Now select the target form factor and API level, and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Now select the target form factor and API level, and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Mobile Engagement requires API level 10 minimum (Android 2.3.3).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Mobile Engagement requires API level 10 minimum (Android 2.3.3).

trans-unit.source: We'll now add an activity to our simple app, which will be its main and only screen.
trans-unit.target: We'll now add an activity to our simple app, which will be its main and only screen.

trans-unit.source: Make sure **Blank Activity** is selected, and then lick **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Make sure **Blank Activity** is selected, and then lick **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the final screen of the wizard, you can leave everything as is for the purposes of this tutorial, and then click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: In the final screen of the wizard, you can leave everything as is for the purposes of this tutorial, and then click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: Android Studio now creates the demo app into which we will integrate Mobile Engagement.
trans-unit.target: Android Studio now creates the demo app into which we will integrate Mobile Engagement.

trans-unit.source: Include the SDK library in your project
trans-unit.target: Include the SDK library in your project

trans-unit.source: Download and integrate the SDK library
trans-unit.target: Download and integrate the SDK library

trans-unit.source: Download the [Mobile Engagement Android SDK].
trans-unit.target: Download the [Mobile Engagement Android SDK].

trans-unit.source: Extract the archive file to a folder in your computer.
trans-unit.target: Extract the archive file to a folder in your computer.

trans-unit.source: Identify the .jar library for the current version of this SDK and copy it to the Clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Identify the .jar library for the current version of this SDK and copy it to the Clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the **Project** section (1) and paste the .jar in the libs folder (2).
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the **Project** section (1) and paste the .jar in the libs folder (2).

trans-unit.source: Sync your project to load the library.
trans-unit.target: Sync your project to load the library.

trans-unit.source: Connect your app to Mobile Engagement backend with the Connection String
trans-unit.target: Connect your app to Mobile Engagement backend with the Connection String

trans-unit.source: Copy the following lines of code into the activity creation (must be done only in one place of your application, usually the main activity).
trans-unit.target: Copy the following lines of code into the activity creation (must be done only in one place of your application, usually the main activity).

trans-unit.source: Go back to the Azure portal in your app's **Connection Info** page and copy the **Connection String**.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the Azure portal in your app's **Connection Info** page and copy the **Connection String**.

trans-unit.source: Paste it in the `setConnectionString` parameter to replace the example provided as shown below (The AppId and Sdkkey were hidden below).
trans-unit.target: Paste it in the `setConnectionString` parameter to replace the example provided as shown below (The AppId and Sdkkey were hidden below).

trans-unit.source: **EngagementConfiguration** and **EngagementAgent** will probably show as unresolved (in red in the code).
trans-unit.target: **EngagementConfiguration** and **EngagementAgent** will probably show as unresolved (in red in the code).

trans-unit.source: Click each of the unresolved classes, and then press Alt+Enter to automatically resolve them.
trans-unit.target: Click each of the unresolved classes, and then press Alt+Enter to automatically resolve them.

trans-unit.source: Add permissions and a service declaration
trans-unit.target: Add permissions and a service declaration

trans-unit.source: Add these permissions to the Manifest.xml of your project immediately before or after the `<application>` tag:
trans-unit.target: Add these permissions to the Manifest.xml of your project immediately before or after the `<application>` tag:

trans-unit.source: The result should be as shown below:
trans-unit.target: The result should be as shown below:

trans-unit.source: Add the following between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags to declare the agent service:
trans-unit.target: Add the following between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags to declare the agent service:

trans-unit.source: In the code you just pasted, replace `"<Your application name>"` in the label.
trans-unit.target: In the code you just pasted, replace `"<Your application name>"` in the label.

trans-unit.source: This is displayed in the **Settings** menu where users can see services running on the device.
trans-unit.target: This is displayed in the **Settings** menu where users can see services running on the device.

trans-unit.source: You can add the word "Service" in that label for example.
trans-unit.target: You can add the word "Service" in that label for example.

trans-unit.source: Send a screen to Mobile Engagement
trans-unit.target: Send a screen to Mobile Engagement

trans-unit.source: In order to start sending data and ensuring that the users are active, you must send at least one screen (Activity) to the Mobile Engagement backend.
trans-unit.target: In order to start sending data and ensuring that the users are active, you must send at least one screen (Activity) to the Mobile Engagement backend.

trans-unit.source: We will achieve this by subclassing our Activity with **EngagementActivity** our SDK provides.
trans-unit.target: We will achieve this by subclassing our Activity with **EngagementActivity** our SDK provides.

trans-unit.source: In order to to that, replace the super class of **MainActivity**, which is before **ActionBarActivity**, with **EngagementActivity**, as shown below:
trans-unit.target: In order to to that, replace the super class of **MainActivity**, which is before **ActionBarActivity**, with **EngagementActivity**, as shown below:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Do not forget to resolve the class if it appears in red by clicking it and pressing Alt+Enter.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Do not forget to resolve the class if it appears in red by clicking it and pressing Alt+Enter.

trans-unit.source: Check that your app is connected with real-time monitoring
trans-unit.target: Check that your app is connected with real-time monitoring

trans-unit.source: This section shows you how to make sure that your app connects to the Mobile Engagement backend by using the Mobile Engagement's real-time monitoring feature.
trans-unit.target: This section shows you how to make sure that your app connects to the Mobile Engagement backend by using the Mobile Engagement's real-time monitoring feature.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to your Mobile Engagement portal.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to your Mobile Engagement portal.

trans-unit.source: From your Azure portal, ensure you're in the app we're using for this project, and then click the **Engage** button at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: From your Azure portal, ensure you're in the app we're using for this project, and then click the **Engage** button at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: You will land in the **Settings** page of your Engagement portal for your app.
trans-unit.target: You will land in the **Settings** page of your Engagement portal for your app.

trans-unit.source: From there, click the **Monitor** tab as shown below.
trans-unit.target: From there, click the **Monitor** tab as shown below.

trans-unit.source: The monitor is ready to show you any device in real time, which will start your app.
trans-unit.target: The monitor is ready to show you any device in real time, which will start your app.

trans-unit.source: Back in Android Studio, start your app either in the monitor or in a connected device by clicking the green triangle and then selecting your device.
trans-unit.target: Back in Android Studio, start your app either in the monitor or in a connected device by clicking the green triangle and then selecting your device.

trans-unit.source: If it worked, you should now see one session in the monitor!
trans-unit.target: If it worked, you should now see one session in the monitor!

trans-unit.source: **Congratulations!** You succeeded in completing the first step of this tutorial with an app that connects to the Mobile Engagement backend, which is already sending data.
trans-unit.target: **Congratulations!** You succeeded in completing the first step of this tutorial with an app that connects to the Mobile Engagement backend, which is already sending data.

trans-unit.source: Enable push notifications and in-app messaging
trans-unit.target: Enable push notifications and in-app messaging

trans-unit.source: Mobile Engagement allows you to interact with and REACH your users with push notifications and in-app messaging in the context of campaigns.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Engagement allows you to interact with and REACH your users with push notifications and in-app messaging in the context of campaigns.

trans-unit.source: This module is called REACH in the Mobile Engagement portal.
trans-unit.target: This module is called REACH in the Mobile Engagement portal.

trans-unit.source: The following sections sets up your app to receive them.
trans-unit.target: The following sections sets up your app to receive them.

trans-unit.source: Enable in-app messaging
trans-unit.target: Enable in-app messaging

trans-unit.source: Copy the in-app messaging resources below into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.
trans-unit.target: Copy the in-app messaging resources below into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.

trans-unit.source: Copy the resources to your project through the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Copy the resources to your project through the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Navigate back to your SDK download content and copy the 'res' folder.
trans-unit.target: Navigate back to your SDK download content and copy the 'res' folder.

trans-unit.source: Go back to Android Studio, select the 'main' directory of your project files, and then paste it to add the resources to your project.
trans-unit.target: Go back to Android Studio, select the 'main' directory of your project files, and then paste it to add the resources to your project.

trans-unit.source: Specify an icon for notifications
trans-unit.target: Specify an icon for notifications

trans-unit.source: The following code defines the icon that is used to be displayed both in app and system notifications.
trans-unit.target: The following code defines the icon that is used to be displayed both in app and system notifications.

trans-unit.source: Although this is optional for in-app notifications, it is mandatory for system notifications.
trans-unit.target: Although this is optional for in-app notifications, it is mandatory for system notifications.

trans-unit.source: Android rejects system notifications with invalid icons.
trans-unit.target: Android rejects system notifications with invalid icons.

trans-unit.source: This XML snippet is to be pasted into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.
trans-unit.target: This XML snippet is to be pasted into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you are using an icon that exists in one of the **drawable** folders (like ``engagement_close.png``).
trans-unit.target: Make sure you are using an icon that exists in one of the **drawable** folders (like ``engagement_close.png``).

trans-unit.source: We don't support **mipmap** folders.
trans-unit.target: We don't support **mipmap** folders.

trans-unit.source: It's just an example to show the syntax.
trans-unit.target: It's just an example to show the syntax.

trans-unit.source: You should of course use an icon that is suitable for notifications per [Android design guidelines](http://developer.android.com/design/patterns/notifications.html).
trans-unit.target: You should of course use an icon that is suitable for notifications per [Android design guidelines](http://developer.android.com/design/patterns/notifications.html).

trans-unit.source: You should not use the **launcher** icon.
trans-unit.target: You should not use the **launcher** icon.

trans-unit.source: It has a different resolution and is usually in the mipmap folders, which we don't support.
trans-unit.target: It has a different resolution and is usually in the mipmap folders, which we don't support.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] To be sure to use correct icon resolutions, you can look at [those examples](https://www.google.com/design/icons).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] To be sure to use correct icon resolutions, you can look at [those examples](https://www.google.com/design/icons).

trans-unit.source: Scroll down to the **Notification** section, click an icon, and then click `PNGS` to download the icon drawable set.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down to the **Notification** section, click an icon, and then click `PNGS` to download the icon drawable set.

trans-unit.source: You can see what drawable folders with which resolution to use for each version of the icon.
trans-unit.target: You can see what drawable folders with which resolution to use for each version of the icon.

trans-unit.source: Enable your app to receive GCM push notifications
trans-unit.target: Enable your app to receive GCM push notifications

trans-unit.source: Enter your gcm:sender metadata and copy and paste the following into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.
trans-unit.target: Enter your gcm:sender metadata and copy and paste the following into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.

trans-unit.source: The hidden value below (with stars) is the `project number` obtained from your Google Play console.
trans-unit.target: The hidden value below (with stars) is the `project number` obtained from your Google Play console.

trans-unit.source: The \n is intentional so make sure that you end the project number with it.
trans-unit.target: The \n is intentional so make sure that you end the project number with it.

trans-unit.source: Paste the code below into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.
trans-unit.target: Paste the code below into your Manifest.xml between the `<application>` and `</application>` tags.

trans-unit.source: Replace the package name
trans-unit.target: Replace the package name

trans-unit.source: Add the last set of permissions that are highlighted before the `<application>` tag.
trans-unit.target: Add the last set of permissions that are highlighted before the `<application>` tag.

trans-unit.source: Replace `<Your package name>` by the actual package name of your application.
trans-unit.target: Replace `<Your package name>` by the actual package name of your application.

trans-unit.source: Grant Mobile Engagement access to your GCM API Key
trans-unit.target: Grant Mobile Engagement access to your GCM API Key

trans-unit.source: To allow Mobile Engagement to send push notifications on your behalf, you need to grant it access to your API Key.
trans-unit.target: To allow Mobile Engagement to send push notifications on your behalf, you need to grant it access to your API Key.

trans-unit.source: This is done by configuring and entering your key into the Mobile Engagement portal.
trans-unit.target: This is done by configuring and entering your key into the Mobile Engagement portal.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to your Mobile Engagement portal
trans-unit.target: Navigate to your Mobile Engagement portal

trans-unit.source: From your Azure portal, ensure you're in the app we're using for this project, and then click the **Engage** button at the bottom:
trans-unit.target: From your Azure portal, ensure you're in the app we're using for this project, and then click the **Engage** button at the bottom:

trans-unit.source: You are now in the **Settings** page in your Engagement portal.
trans-unit.target: You are now in the **Settings** page in your Engagement portal.

trans-unit.source: From there, click the **Native Push** section to enter your GCM Key:
trans-unit.target: From there, click the **Native Push** section to enter your GCM Key:

trans-unit.source: Click the **Edit** icon in front of **API Key** in the **GCM Settings** section as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Click the **Edit** icon in front of **API Key** in the **GCM Settings** section as shown below:

trans-unit.source: In the pop-up, paste the GCM Server Key you obtained in the section [Enable Google Cloud Messaging](#register), and then click **Ok**.
trans-unit.target: In the pop-up, paste the GCM Server Key you obtained in the section [Enable Google Cloud Messaging](#register), and then click **Ok**.

trans-unit.source: You're all set.
trans-unit.target: You're all set.

trans-unit.source: Now we will verify that you have correctly carried out this basic integration.
trans-unit.target: Now we will verify that you have correctly carried out this basic integration.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Make sure you build, start with this new code, exit the app, and wait about 1 minute before doing the following steps.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Make sure you build, start with this new code, exit the app, and wait about 1 minute before doing the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Send a notification to your app
trans-unit.target: Send a notification to your app

trans-unit.source: We will now create a simple push notification campaign that sends a push notification to our app.
trans-unit.target: We will now create a simple push notification campaign that sends a push notification to our app.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the **REACH** tab in your Mobile Engagement portal.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the **REACH** tab in your Mobile Engagement portal.

trans-unit.source: Click **New announcement** to create your push notification campaign.
trans-unit.target: Click **New announcement** to create your push notification campaign.

trans-unit.source: Set up the first field of your campaign through the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Set up the first field of your campaign through the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Name your campaign with any name you like.
trans-unit.target: Name your campaign with any name you like.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Delivery type** as *System notification / Simple*: This is the simple Android push notification type that features a title and a small line of text.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Delivery type** as *System notification / Simple*: This is the simple Android push notification type that features a title and a small line of text.

trans-unit.source: Select **Delivery time** as *Any time* to allow the app to receive a notification whether the app is started or not.
trans-unit.target: Select **Delivery time** as *Any time* to allow the app to receive a notification whether the app is started or not.

trans-unit.source: In the notification text, type the title, which will be in bold in the push.
trans-unit.target: In the notification text, type the title, which will be in bold in the push.

trans-unit.source: Then type your message.
trans-unit.target: Then type your message.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down, and in the **Content** section, select **Notification only**.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down, and in the **Content** section, select **Notification only**.

trans-unit.source: You're done setting the most basic campaign possible, now scroll down again and create your campaign to save it!
trans-unit.target: You're done setting the most basic campaign possible, now scroll down again and create your campaign to save it!

trans-unit.source: Last step: Activate your campaign.
trans-unit.target: Last step: Activate your campaign.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
